Award.AwardTitle: New Capabilities for the Enzo Community Code in the Petascale Era
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0808184
Norman

Enzo is a three-dimensional parallel adaptive mesh refinement hybrid (fluid plus particle) open-source community code for astrophysical and cosmological simulations developed at the Laboratory for Computational Astrophysics (LCA) at the University of California-San Diego. Enzo underpins the research of many astronomers in areas as diverse as primordial star formation, galaxy formation, the intergalactic medium, galaxy clusters, interstellar turbulence, and Galactic star formation. The arrival of petascale computing platforms will take these and other researches into a new realm of physical realism, but not without appropriate parallel application software, whose development requires effort by an interdisciplinary team of domain scientists, applied mathematicians, and computer scientists, such as has been assembled at the LCA. The present project will add radiation magnetohydrodynamics capabilities to Enzo within a new parallel framework designed for petascale platforms, and will include three annual software releases and two user workshops. These capabilities will enable larger-scale and higher dynamic range simulations in cosmological structure formation, interstellar turbulence, and star formation, as well as open up new possibilities wherever complex physics and high spatial dynamic range are needed.

In addition to direct research impacts, this work will serve as a springboard for inter-departmental collaborations, bringing together graduate students from mathematics, physics and computer science into a coordinated program. The community-code nature of Enzo, distributed under UCSD policies for wide access under copyright, and with the user-friendly packaging and support which are part of this project, will enable a wide range of multiscale applications throughout astrophysics and other disciplines to harness petascale computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer simulation as a means to understand complex natural phenomena is now a standard part of scientific research. In astronomical research, computer simulation is vital since what we are studying cannot be accessed except through remote observing. Computational astrophysics is the discipline that creates computer simulations of astronomical objects so as to better understand their nature and origin.

The purpose of this grant was to improve upon a specific computer simulation tool called Enzo developed at UCSD by adding to it new physics capabilities, and also adapting it to run on today's most powerful supercomputers (referred to as petascale computers.) Enzo software is publicly available through its website, and is in use by over a dozen of research groups internal and external to UCSD.

The intellectual merit of this research project derives from two new physics modeling capabilities added to Enzo: magnetic fields and radiation transport. The addition of these two capabilities, as well as the ability to tap the awesome computing power of petascale systems, has enabled entirely new kinds of computer simulations to improve our understanding of how stars form in the Milky Way galaxy, how magnetic fields are generated in clusters of galaxies, and how the first generation of galaxies that formed after the Big Bang ionized the entire visible universe. 

The broader impact of this research grant is that by making the software publicly available with excellent documentation and tutorials, we have broadened the community of users and co-developers significantly. No fewer than 25 researchers from a dozen research groups, most of whom are graduate students and postdocs, are contributing to the development of Enzo by virtue of our embracing open source software development practices to the fullest.
